mj_-WHBVR4aupC120XJOpw.text: When it comes to British food, the first thing one typically thinks of is either food that one would normally get at a bar, or the image of Gordon Ramsay yelling at someone for a spectacular kitchen cock-up ( no offense to the man, since he has quite a few restaurants here in town ). I can't necessarily deny that Cornish Pasty itself is a bar, one especially well-stocked with all manner of beer and spirits. However, to simply label it as bar food would really be missing the entire point of this restaurant -- focusing specifically on one item and refining it to delicious perfection, and Cornish Pasty delivers on that front!  As the name implies, this restaurant focuses specifically on Cornish pasties, a rich, buttery pastry filled with meat and vegetables, though they offer some sweet options for dessert. The history of Cornish pasties is itself discussed on the menu, though that is a discussion for another time.   Cornish Pasty is actually one of my personal favorite restaurants in town, though I have not been able to come here at all until now, ever since they moved from their original location in the Commercial Center District on Sahara and Maryland. As I was in the area for a work-related function, however, it was the perfect opportunity to come in and have some of my favorite foods that I haven't eaten in a while. I ended up ordering a lot of food -- the leek, potato and Stilton cheese soup, their Scotch egg, the Guinness stew pasty, and their banoffee pie for dessert.  Of course, the first items to come out were the soup and the Scotch egg -- and they were both delicious. The Scotch egg was perfectly savory, with the honey mustard sauce and the light salad being excellent counterpoints to both, but the soup was really one of the two items I came in for ( the other being the banoffee pie ). Rich, creamy, and a tad funky in a good way from the Stilton cheese, it was perfect both by itself and with the crusty bread that came with the soup. I admit that one of my favorite things to do with the bread is it butter it and then dip it into the soup to make it a bit richer from the butter.  As for the pasty itself, it was perfect. The pastry was flaky, buttery and tender -- and the filling was delicious. It was impossible to go wrong with it -- chunks of tender beef and vegetables stewed in a Guinness gravy ( and I could definitely taste a bit of the Guinness in the sauce! ) and layered with cabbage, cheese and leeks, together with the strong bite of the chive-laced sour cream, made for a perfect meal. It was so hard to keep from inhaling it since it came fresh out of the oven!  As for the dessert, the banoffee pie showcases bananas and toffee, hence the name. And was it as good as I remember: the rich, slightly nutty toffee, the crisp graham cracker crust, and the soft and light bananas made for one of my favorite dessert experiences in town!  During my meal, I noticed that even though it wasn't too busy, it took a while for me to be seen. Normally I would consider this a bad thing, but since my work at the time involved walking around in the hot sun mapping the street, it was actually a welcome break to just sit back, relax, and cool down with copious amounts of ice water while waiting for the server.  Cornish Pasty is one of those restaurants that knows what it's doing by focusing on one specialty item -- and they have a lot of different pasty options to choose from, all of them flavorful and delicious! They even proudly have vegan and vegetarian parties for those that don't eat meat which are just as good as, if not better than, the meat-filled ones ( take THAT, Piers Morgan! ). If you want a uniquely British food with a history as rich as it's pastry, this is the place to be. You won't regret coming here, I can assure you that much!

photos.caption: Photo of Cornish Pasty - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The inside of the Guinness stew pasty.
Photo of Cornish Pasty - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The banoffee pie. 5/5 -- rich, sweet and a perfect way to end the meal. My personal favorite of the desserts here!
Photo of Cornish Pasty - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Their Guinness Stew pasty. 5/5 -- so good. So hearty. So irresistible.

m2EmT8sPDPqYwQX-a85oQg.text: My friends and I came here on a Saturday night. We ordered three pasties (or pastries) to try and share plus we stayed and played darts. I only was able to try one of the meals but from what I tried it was delicious, only wishing there was more filling... but definitely comfort food and hit the spot!     Being the weekend it was pretty busy, but the service was great. Unfortunately we didnt get to stay as long as I would have liked but I'll definitely be back to try more of their menu!

BbGj9gXj-c8sNvVi7--cFw.text: How does one explain what a pasty is without using the phrase "really, really good"? Spoiler alert--you can't. They're a sophisticated take on the midwestern pizza puff. They're like a Hot Pocket, but made with love instead of machinery. In short: pasty is tasty.  Their beer list is colossal. I had a hard time deciding between a brew or a reasonably priced ($4) car bomb. I chose the former and ended up with a banana bread flavored beer. I was initially skeptical about my choice, but the banana flavor was just right and not overwhelming at all, so it actually paired quite well with my entree.  I had the veggie rosemary chicken pasty. It was jam-packed with vegetarian "chicken," roasted red peppers, potatoes, and Brie cheese. Upon first sight, it was a lot bigger than I thought it would be. My only gripe about the dish was that it seemed to be devoid of Brie cheese, which was the main selling point for me. I realize that Brie has a very mild flavor, but it's my favorite cheese (I sometimes joke that I was named after it) and I'm certain that I would've noticed if it was there.  I'm docking a star from this (otherwise) great experience because the service was a bit spotty and our meal took quite a while to come out. The whole experience kind of moved in slow-motion from start to finish.

KO2NKS1W7BtbngCNArrjbw.text: We stopped by this place while in the art district. The inside of this place is a bit different, especially with the church pews. I enjoyed the different feel but the chairs we sat on felt a bit garage sale ish. Not really a big deal.   We ordered a lamb pasty and it was big and tasted pretty good. Since my wife and I were sharing it they split it onto two plates for us without even asking, which was very nice. My only complaint is the pasty come with no sides or anything. The amount of food is enough but just by itself looks and feels a bit boring. I would have made the pasty a little smaller and served with a small salad or roasted vegetables.   We got an apple pasty for dessert and that was really good, especially with the ice cream. That was a lot of food, it really should be shared.   Overall, I enjoyed the food here. Our waitress was very nice and professional. The problem is that the food took way too long to be served. The place was pretty empty so I do not see why it should have taken so long. Luckily we did not bring our son or he would have gone crazy. Because of the extremely slow service we would not come back. Hopefully the service is not normally like this.

pA0nU-0C5cfOAoY7sFwnIA.text: After viewing the menu online for this restaruant and hearing amazing things since I moved here, I was really excited to try this place out. The menu showed several amazing sounding options that I could eat despite my dairy allergy. Personally I enjoy meat in some dishes, but going for the vegan option gives me a safe place to enjoy food without worrying about itching and having tummy problems later. They have something like 6-10 vegetarian options on the menu all the time, but was told that the vegan options for the day were the one on the menu and a curry they could whip up if I wanted. I was really excited to have a gravy that I could eat because of it's description in some of their other vegan recipes but only had ketchup and steak sauce. When I asked about the vegan options, I was told that this isn't a vegan restaraunt, which I understood going in but the representation on their website made me feel as though there might be a little more choice for me there.   Please do not be mistaken, the food we were served was yummy and the place smelled like heaven. I just wish I could have had more of a choice so I could have eaten more of it because of the expectation I got after reading the menu on their page. Next time I think I will call first and find out my options before coming out

FUwCmZCzGU3qXjmDPU_d6Q.text: I love the history behind this place and the origination of the "The Pasti"! The Pasti dates back to when the MINING industry was thriving and at its peak. Due to the arsenic in the caves, women would make them with thick crimped edges so miners could hold onto while eating. After eating, the miners would discard the crimped edges in the hallow mines, which they believe kept the ghost 'knockers' content. So food was never wasted. INSIDE, the bar has a great ambiance and couches surrounding it for comfort. Old Jameson bottles dripping with wax, gives it a low light intimate glow. Great for conversations! The DRINKS are nice and strong and the food here is exceptional. Overall great atmosphere to start the night off with friends.

sVncHdLf7_6PEklNasZO3g.text: **THE WORST CUSTOMER SERVICE!! I have been to cornish pasty before & had decent service & the food was spot on! However! When deciding to eat there for my birthday was a terrible mistake!   When 8 of my friends entered the restaurant we decided to get seating towards the end of the bar, then we were told by some stuck up brunette bartender snapped, "You guys can't sit there!" Which turn me off right away! So we decided to sit closer to the the bar and the bartender seemed she did not want us there. When she handed my friend and I menus she did not say one word to us! That was it & left & decided to get a table instead. No one was available to seat us so we sat ourselves down. Shortly after someone came to take our orders and everything seemed to be rectified... so I thought!   Then we had someone take over for our waiter and this guy had the personality of a washing machine! He did not check on our drink see how we were doing, & he wasn't busy at all. So that annoyed me through the night, and it also was my birthday so that added to it. It wasn't until we had to pay when the real issue came about. They refuse to split a check of eight people! The last time I went there they had no problem splitting my check last time! For some reason the second time around "their register was unable to split the check, could you write who ordered what" I didn't go there to do all that! in disbelief I asked another waitress if they really couldn't split the bill. She replied; NO! I lost it! I told everyone to get me the hell out of there! I just payed and got the hell out of there! By far the worst service I have ever had.   I feel like I need to say that the food is delicious! The food is the one thing that made me want to come back to this place so I'm not just shitting on this place. but I feel to prideful to ever step foot in that shit service ever again.

fa2vnwHF-_BoRo1to2ndNQ.text: I didn't know what a pasty was until coming here and I quickly learned that they are amazing!! The first time I came here I had their fries as an appetizer and the apple pie pasty for dessert. It's absolutely delicious! It's basically baked apple pie in a thick crust, served with ice cream and caramel.   The next time I stopped in, I tried a Cornish pasty for dinner. It was kinda like a pizza hot pocket. They actually have a large menu with many different fillings.   This is more of a bar than a restaurant but they have some tables. The bar is huge though! The bartenders are super friendly and the environment is fun. They have pool tables and darts too.

Photo of Cornish Pasty - Las Vegas, NV, United States

VQnY_cb3rjw0eBm6ROw7Rw.text: Man, it really does not get any better than this! This is my favorite British pub. Wife and I had the chicken pot pie pasty and the Bangers and Mash pasty. Each one of these are not actual pies and sausage and mash potatoes on a plate. Each one of the entrees ordered is pretty much  a pasty with the filling that you ordered. So the chicken pot pie is actually a pasty filled with chicken pot pie. The bangers and mash is a pasty that is filled with sausage/mash/gravy inside.  Bangers and mash was DELISH! The chicken pot pie was good, but the bangers and mash was what really stood out Scotch Egg was good too. Bit overpriced for one egg, but it was still good.   Service was great as well!  We played darts as well. Scoreboard was a bit run down, but it was really fun and it was real darts. None of this plastic BS. Kudos!  Parking is a bit tricky. The Punchcode parking lot allows Cornish Pasty parking after 6pm on weekends.  This neighborhood looks like a ghetto neighborhood that's in the process of being gentrified.  Needless to say, we will definitely be coming back. This is now one of our favorite stops!

-APJ_C0tF2lGi2jtYOKYlw.text: Atmosphere is great, I like the look and feel. I had the Guava Lava drink and that was delish. My boyfriend had the Pizza Porter and that was good too. We decided to split the Cottage Pasty. Sadly, I was not pleased. It was bland and mine was lukewarm. I was hoping it would come out piping hot.  The rent part part my boyfriends portion of the meal was hot I saw steam coming out, so I thought mine would be the same. NOPE. Luke warm, some parts were even still cold.  Besides me being unhappy with the food. The service and people are great.  Maybe you will have better luck than me.

SibQjPUUKgnzaJJImQwECQ.text: Fun and creative bar/restaurant in the downtown area  The decor is pretty gothic but trendy.  They have pews for tables (but not open during the day).  This is like a cross of Victorian England and a modern pub.  The pastys are, it is often said, like upgraded "hot pockets."  They have a ton of flavors.  The meatball one is quite good.  So is the traditional Scottish pie (and Shepherd's pie).  People like the cheeseburger one.  Maybe I would return for that.  You can't substitute ingredients.  They are pre-made in house, closed, then baked.  If you take one to go they can give it to you "half-baked," and you can finish it off at home.  The desserts are really good! Try the one that is toffee, but tastes like bread pudding.  There are sweet pastys, too, with ice cream.  I like that they serve hot tea with a pitcher, as it should be.

bZEKE1jzkhHf3_OAtae0mw.text: I got the Guinness Stew Pasty. It was my first pasty ever. Overall, not bad.  - solid choice  - pasty was flaky (in a good way) - very heavy food - came with sour cream that made the pasty taste even better   - great service - $4 Irish car bombs   I also tried the tikka masala one. - liked this one more a little more than the Guinness Stew  - came with a yogurt sauce  - another solid choice

photos.caption: Photo of Cornish Pasty - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Guinness Stew

rVG8YqVxoR_4TOXu4k0yTA.text: What is a Cornish pasty, you might ask? Simply put, it's a pastry, filled with savory goodness, much like a calzone.  Because "Cornish" is half the name, I decided to go with a traditional shepherd's pie, with lamb, mashed potatoes, peas and carrots, and cheese. I loved the flaky pasty, but my fillings seemed a bit underseasoned. The wine-based sauce on the side added a bit more flavor, so if you go with the shepherd's pie, don't forget to dip!  My husband's choice, while non-traditional, was really great! The Italian is much like the aforementioned calzone, with pepperoni, salami, capocollo, ham, and mozzarella, with a side of marinara. That pasty was stuffed to the max, and both of our selections were so filling that we only ate half, saving the rest for a savory dinner.  I wish I had been more adventurous in my menu choice, because now I'm intrigued by the other offbeat offerings, like the Cuban and the Reuben (two of best sandwiches ever, IMHO). Guess I'll have to come back to Cornish Pasty to find my favorite!

CgtBXwGDmqUIRDVIJH4P5g.text: First Timer and ImpressedRustic decor. Food is delicious! We ordered: Chicken Pot Pie, The Pilgrim, eggplant Parmesan and the. All of them VERY tasty and Fresh! Also tried the chips. Basically fries with garlic but, still on a different level. Will be back!

4qnvNgQvzRqEnOGlN21S9w.text: I sure wish you would of updated your hours on yelp!! We love you so much but are bummed you were closed on 4th of July!! Next time, please update your hours on yelp!!

z6fel2M7WfiGgxnkgUvp-Q.text: Ok, so aside from attending the Dark Arts Market I decided to try the food.   I didn't find it to be full of flavor (My opinion) but nonetheless, it was still good! I'm willing to give it a second shot. There's plenty of choices!   Almost any item you order is shareable with groups.  Of course, it's going to be a little costly but that's to be expected since it's downtown by the Art District.   The restaurant has a "Hipster" feel to it and seems to draw in the younger crowd. Always a full house and a cool history behind this place.   Overall I rate it 4/5 stars.

TeT5KbA3pZdGTOYpRqBwgw.text: Came in for drinks when bar hopping in the Arts District.  It was a Sunday night so not very busy.  Started with a Pucker Up to drink and got a Chicken Tikka Pasty to eat.  I sat at the bar.  Service was not great and food was just ok.  I really wanted to love this place but it was a miss for me.

2-nzGJsQIhDfOvONUC51Ew.text: Grown up hot pockets! What's not to love?! The restaurant had a cool vibe and atmosphere. The service wasn't bad. They were out of the chilled bean dip we tried to order, though. The pasties were quite tasty - it was our first time trying them, and we were impressed.

0ky1UJVs7SaSMcPCk_X_9Q.text: What is a pasty?? and why was I pronouncing it paste-y like my skin, rather than past-ee like I am supposed to pronounce it?  Last Saturday night after the Rebels won a nailbaiter vs Boise State, we got a rita and some nachos at Paradise Cantina.  Then I decided we should continue dinner at Cornish Pasty Co. because it was nearby and everyone was rating it highly.  We sat at the bar, which has some very cold barstools!!!  There is a purse hook underneath the bar which is a great feature.  Our server was very cool, did not catch her name.  I got iced green tea which was great.  Eric R. is still not on the black tea bandwagon and only likes hot green tea, so he stuck with water rather than get British black tea.  I ordered the pilgrim (roasted turkey/chicken with grilled onions, stuffing, and sweet potato) served with red wine gravy and cranberry sauce (gelled, the best!) - and Eric R. got the chicken tikka masala with the mint yogurt sauce (tahini was the other option).  While we waited for our meals to be prepared, we watched a chef in front of us at the bar prepare the lamb vindaloo pasties (what I almost ordered, and will definitely get next time).  I was intrigued because the night before, I had learned how to make dumplings.  Now in front of my eyes, a chef was making essentially a giant dumpling, using egg wash instead of water to seal the dough but crimping it similarly!  I felt my parallel universes collide.  Our pasties came out piping hot and cut in half.  Eric R. learned something new about me that he didn't know (and that is hard for a married couple): that I really like gelled cranberry sauce and even enjoy the canned one.  I never think about it though so I never buy it or talk about it!  The pilgrim was very delicious.  Eric R. asked to swap halves so we ended up eating each other's first halves.  The chicken tikka masala was very moist and the curry sauce was spot on.  Eric R. thought it was a tad too spicy for him which means mild for me :)  Then we started on our second halves and ended up switching plates entirely.  He really liked the red wine gravy and I was quite happy with the CTM.  The vibe is cool and it was a hot spot just for people to drink while we were there.  It is located just north/left of Komol.  Whenever I go to Commercial Center, I will have to choose between Cornish Pasty, Komol, and Ma Dang...that is tough!  There is an extensive vegetarian menu too.  Cheers!

fD8WqZaATfx_K6PZe8BWQg.text: Located in the same plaza as Green Door, Lotus of Siam, and right next to Komol in commercial center plaza. Ample parking galore. Just watch for the slanted parking spaces and which way your car is facing!  I came here with my boyfriend after a show at the Onyx. Love the concept. Punk rock playing over the speakers. Center bar with metal swivel seats and park-benchlike support was a nice touch. Whoever designed this place deserves props!   AMBIANCE:  Make sure to sit at the bar to catch the guys making pasties. (Pronounced "pass-teas" and not "paste-stee" like the nipple tape in porn I believe lol) it's cool seeing them make a whole batch, but I worry about when they make a whole batch tray of 20ish. What do they do with the rest when they've baked them all and served people? Refrigerate them? It was a pretty dead night for a friday considering that there was First Friday going on.   Love the intimate low-lighting. The design for this bar is cool. Picture polished wood and beer. Clean place. One side of the place has two-seater tables with the same unique park-bench swivel chairs. The other side has two long tables with long benches for bigger parties. I wonder what this place looks like super crowded.  DRINKS:  We ordered the Union Jack IPA and its darker cousin the Wookey Jack IPA. Union Jack is hoppy (IPA, I know) while the Wookey Jack is also hoppy, but more bitter in taste. I like the fact that they carry both. These beers paired well with the pasties we ordered.  APPETIZERS:  To start we got the Hand-Cut fries with the option of garlic and/or jalapenos over it. We greedily got both. This was amazing. Perfect bar food to soak up alcohol. Freshly cracked pepper and sea salt seasoned this dish so well. These fries set them apart from other cardboard-tasting carbon copies.   The leek, potato, and stilton soup ($3.50 cup) was creamy, well-made, and not bland at all. For those who don't know, stilton is a type of rich cheese. I should have asked for the bowl ($5ish). The cheese flavor went beautifully with the leeks and potatoes giving it a hearty flavor. Came a couple slices of bread and butter.  PASTY: My Bangers & Mash pasty was okay. Really drying on the inside including the hard puff pastry encasing it. It came with an excellent red wine gravy sauce so maybe I should have asked for more of that. Although it was okay to eat, it was really salty and dense. I expected maybe a sauce/liquid/melted something on the inside when I stab it with my fork. It would have made the dish more palatable and not just a literal meat-cake.   True, I dipped it in my gravy, but it was still a little difficult to eat. Meat was a bit too tough. Expected it to be a bit more tender.  Maybe I'll try a different pasty next time. The appetizers and ambiance were excellent. I had a bite of my boyfriend's adobada pasty and that was bomb. We're definitely coming back for this one!

photos.caption: Photo of Cornish Pasty - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Cream of leek, potato, stilton cheese soup comes with bread and butter. Cup is $3.50. Bowl is $5ish.
Photo of Cornish Pasty - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Intimate two-seaters on one side of the restaurant.
Photo of Cornish Pasty - Las Vegas, NV, United States. They have 12 different vegan and vegetarian options!!

sD2Bqmc_os8v99QL_My8JA.text: After seeing a sign on the door for what felt like three years, Cornish Pasty is finally open and ready for business.  And the best news?  They have tons of vegetarian options!  Located in the same plaza as Thai staples Komol and Lotus of Siam, Cornish Pasty is a smaller space but cozy and inviting.  Think of it as a local pub with lots of good food.  Speaking of food, we ate a ton of it.  I started off with the Cream of Leek, Potato, and Stilton soup (fyi: this is vegetarian/no chicken stock).  The cup is a good portion, and served with two large pieces of homemade bread and homemade butter.  It's a steal for $3.50.  Although I really enjoyed it, the Stilton cheese it might make the soup a little salty for some people.  As for the pasties, I wanted something more traditional and ordered the Cheese and Onion.  It tasted great and everything was cooked well, but I couldn't bring myself to use the ketchup or marina that came with it.  My husband had the Veggie Chicken Tikka Masala and his was really good as well.  There was a nice blend of spices and it came with a side of mint-yogurt dressing that we both enjoyed.    Cornish Pasty also offers a decent beer selection and a 14-oz will set you back $6.   I loved the atmosphere here and all the employees were laid-back and friendly.  Cornish Pasty would even make a good spot just to grab a few drinks for an evening.  I can't speak for the authenticity of the food (which is questionable considering they offer a Mexican pasty), but I do know that I enjoyed what I ordered. The pasties are large and filling so make sure to bring your appetite!  Note to Vegetarians: They use Quorn in about half of their veggie pasties.  While being a popular meat-alternative in the UK, this was the first time my husband and I have ever had it.  I found it to be pretty much the same as most other faux-meats.  I'm sure they could leave it out of the pasties if you asked them.  Note to Vegans: According to their menu, they offer at least two vegan pasties daily.    Note to Omnivores: If my vegetarian pasties tasted awesome, you have nothing to worry about.  And may I suggest trying a vegetarian pasty?

photos.caption: Photo of Cornish Pasty - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Cheese and Onion Pasty with ketchup and marinara on the side.
Photo of Cornish Pasty - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Cream of Leek, Potato, and Stilton soup

ADw_4SuPr2mlpHlyYsCW9w.text: There's three things I love: good food, beer and cool people. All are in abundance at Cornish Pasty.  This was my fourth visit to this location and I can't wait to keep coming back to try new items on the menu.  The service is always great and consistent every time I go here.  Attentive, yet not overbearing.  Friendly, but not in an ass-kissing kind of way.  I dig the food and their style.  Located in Commercial Center right next to the other "famous" Thai restaurant.  I keep joking that this place merely serves fancy Hot PocketsTM. While that may be True it's leaps and bounds above what you may remember having as a kid. Nothing frozen and microwaved here. These bad boys are hand made from scratch right in front of you after placing your order. Part science, part art, with a dash of love gets you some of the best pastry-filled goodness that will ever cross your lips. Don't let the perceived size fool you, these things are very filling and if you order a side you're likely going to need a to-go box.  I re-heated my last order the next day at home and it still tasted fantastic.  Great food, a unique beer selection, cool people and a really nice atmosphere all for a low cost.  My meal is typically no more than 20 bucks with one beer.  Highly recommended.

photos.caption: Photo of Cornish Pasty - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Now in stock.

eiSiePIundDWPOOYKmxmdw.text: Good food good drinks , a pretty hipster place.  They have a nice picture of Aly on their wall which is nice.

IcOeWmcXqrTMcw-qM_PBXg.text: This place is incredible and unique! My friends took me here and I really didn't know what to expect. They're food is authentic, gourmet and so delicious. The menu is also simple to follow and everything I tried was great. I highly recommend this place!

photos.caption: Photo of Cornish Pasty - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Bangers &amp; Mash Pasty w/ red wine gravy. Delicious!

vaxgJDreGAavN1kR9Ex8OA.text: Artistic ambience. Entertainment involved. Can play pool or darts. Good drinks and delicious food. A must go if you visit Vegas. A locals place to hang out.

gTx6ygQ40jLwTIotzMJR2Q.text: I just can't get enough. I absolutely love the red pepper bean soup kicked up with a little habanero. The pastys are quite filling and savory. For me, I normally need a buddy to finish the other half of these monsters. They've quite a few options for the vegetarian and vegans in your party. Beer selection is one of the best around featuring quite a few local breweries as well as more traditional British choices. The staff is knowledgeable and friendly. I'll come here alone or with a group of friends and they're always accommodating.  Cheers!

ZOMxd8QIpilFAa7ov5kN5Q.text: Cool venue but the blandness of the pasty leaves much to be desired. Service is also neglectful

B2iqGzrf0IUZ_Kkg92Ag-A.text: Yum yum! Oh yeah. My bf and I went here for dinner tonight. I was craving some Thai food but lotus of Siam wasn't even opened yet and already had a huge line :/ so we went here instead and boy was it yummy.  My bf had a peppered steak pasty which was pretty good but in my opinion a boys pasty lol I had a carne adovada pasty (my bad for spelling it wrong in the pictures) it was good but I wish I would have ordered a shepherds pie pasty instead omg they looked good. Next time for sure because we will definitely be coming back. The oven baked potatoes delish as well :))))   Definitely a must. Go go go!  Oh yeah and I think my bf would recommend the Scottish crabbie ginger beer (idk if I wrote that correctly)  It was too gingery for me but he absolutely loved it :)
